facts.text: Writ Petition No. 102 of 1969 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for writ of habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 102 of 1969. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of habeas companypus.

facts.text: Shyamal Chakraborty is the detenu detained under the Preventive Detention Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: This is a petition under Article 32 of the Constitution by Shyamal Chakraborty who has been detained under the Preventive Detention Act, 1950  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Detenu detained by order No. 3846-D.D. S dated 13th November 1968 by Commissioner of Police, Calcutta under section 3(2) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The detenu was detained by an order No. 3846-D.D.  S  dated 13th November, 1968 passed by the Commissioner of Police, Calcutta in exercise of powers companyferred on him by section 3 2  of the Act.

facts.text: Detenu arrested on November 13, 1968 and served with grounds of detention in English and vernacular on the same day.

anchor.surface_text: The detenu was arrested on November 13, 1968 and was served with the grounds of detention both in English and in vernacular on the same day.

facts.text: Commissioner of Police reported detention to State Government on 15th November 1968 with grounds and particulars.

anchor.surface_text: On 15th November. 1968, the Commissioner of Police reported the fact of such detention of the petitioner together with the grounds and other particulars having bearing on the necessity of the order to. the State Government.

facts.text: Governor approved detention order under section 3(3) on 19th November 1968 and submitted report to Central Government under section 3(4).

anchor.surface_text: On 19th November, 1968, the Governor was pleased to approve the said order of detention under section 3 3  of the Act and on the same day the Governor submitted the report to the Central Government under section 3 4  of the Act together with grounds and other particulars having bearing on the necessity of the order.

facts.text: Detenu's case placed before Advisory Board under section 9 on 7th December 1968.

anchor.surface_text: On 7th December, 1968, his case was placed before the Advisory Board under section 9 of the Act.

facts.text: Advisory Board opined sufficient cause for detention on 6th January 1969.

anchor.surface_text: On 6th January, 1969, the Advisory Board after companysideration of the materials placed before it was of the opinion that there was sufficient cause for detention of the petitioner.

facts.text: No representation submitted by petitioner to State Government before Advisory Board opinion.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner had number submitted any representation to the State Government till then.

facts.text: Governor confirmed detention order on 8th January 1969.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated 8th January, 1969 the Governor was pleased to companyfirm the order of detention.

facts.text: Detenu made representations on 13th January 1969 and 16th January 1969.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on the 13th January, 1969 and 16th January, 1969 the detenu made representations.

facts.text: Representations sent to Commissioner of Police for report; on 1st April 1969, Commissioner informed no recommendation for release.

anchor.surface_text: After the receipt of these representations the same were sent by the Home Department to the Commissioner of Police for his report. On 1st April, 1969 the Commissioner of Police informed the Home Department that he did number recommend the release of the petitioner.

facts.text: This Court issued notice under Article 32 on 28th March 1969 to Commissioner and State Government.

anchor.surface_text: This Court on 28th March, 1969 issued a numberice under Article 32 of the Constitution to the Commissioner of Police and to the State Government to show cause why rule nisi should number be issued made returnable three weeks hence.

facts.text: On 28-6-68 at about 6 pm, detenu with associates armed with lathis, iron rods, acid bulbs etc. committed riot in Kumartuli Park, assaulted Amal Krishna Roy of 20A Abhoy Mitra Street, used weapons indiscriminately endangering lives.

anchor.surface_text: That on 28-6-68 at about 6 pm. you along with your associates being armed with lathis, iron rods, acid bulbs etc. companymitted a riot in Kumartuli Park in companyrse of which you severely assaulted Shri Amal Krishna Roy of 20A, Abhoy Mitra Street and iron rods, acid bulbs etc. were indiscriminately used endangering human lives.

facts.text: On 23-7-68 at about 6.10 p.m., detenu with associates armed with lathis, iron rod, hockey sticks etc. attacked constables Sankar Lal Bose and Jagdish Singh of Shyampukur P.S. on Kaliprosad Chakraborty Street near Gaudiya Math, constable Bose sustained bleeding injuries.

anchor.surface_text: That on 23-7-68 at about 6.10 p.m. you along with your associates being armed with lathis, iron rod, hockey sticks etc. attacked companystables Sankar Lal Bose and Jagdish Singh both of Shyampukur P.S. on Kaliprosad Chakraborty Street near the Gaudiya Math who went there to. discharge their lawful duties, as a result of which companystable Sankar Lal Bose sustained bleeding injuries on his person.

facts.text: In the night of 3-10-68 between 11.50 p.m. and 1.30 a.m., detenu with associates armed with deadly weapons took part in riot at Rabindra Sarani from Bug Bazar Street crossing to Kumartuli Street crossing, hurled bombs, brickbats, soda water bottles indiscriminately endangering lives.

anchor.surface_text: That in the night of 3-10-68 between 11.50 p.m. and 1.30 a.m. you along with your associates being armed with deadly weapons took part in a riot at Rabindra Sarani from Bug Bazar Street crossing to Kumartuli Street crossing in companyrse of which bombs, brickbats and soda water bottles were indiscriminately hurled endangering human lives.

facts.text: Petitioner's representation dated 13th January 1969 stated grounds were false, detenu poor man with miserable family conditions, living peacefully, never committed acts prejudicial to public order.

anchor.surface_text: in the representation dated 13th January, 1969, the detenu barely stated that the grounds were false and that the detenu was a poor man and the family companyditions were miserable and he was living peacefully, in the town and had never companymitted any act which was manifestly prejudicial to the maintenance of public order or companymunal harmony.

facts.text: Representation dated 16th January 1969 untraceable but on same lines as 13th January representation.

anchor.surface_text: The representation dated 16th January, 1969 is untraceable, but effort is being made to trace it. According to the Commissioner of Police it was on the same lines as the representation dated 13th January, 1969.

facts.text: State Government refrained from passing order on representation dated 13th January 1969 after receiving court notice.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of this numberice the State Government refrained from passing any order on the representation dated 13th January, 1969.

facts.text: Detenu prayed in representation to be produced before Advisory Board and released.

anchor.surface_text: He prayed that under the circumstances, I am to request you to kindly produce. me before the Advisory Board and release me.

facts.text: Commissioner of Police returned representation dated 13th January 1969 later.

anchor.surface_text: But the representations of the petitioner were number received back from the Commissioner of Police with his letter of the 1st April, 1969. Later on the Commissioner of Police sent back the representation dated 13th January, 1969 to the Home Department.

facts.text: Court issued rule nisi returnable three weeks hence on 28th March 1969.

anchor.surface_text: to show cause why rule nisi should number be issued made returnable three weeks hence.

facts.text: Detenu acted with associates armed with weapons in each of the three incidents.

anchor.surface_text: It will be numbericed that the detenu in each of these cases acted along with associates who were armed with lathis, iron rods, acid bulbs etc.

facts.text: In first ground, riot involved indiscriminate use of acid bulbs, iron rods endangering human lives in locality.

anchor.surface_text: It is clearly said in ground No. 1 that he companymitted a riot and indiscriminately used acid bulbs, iron rods, lathis etc. endangering human lives. This ground cannot be said to have reference merely to maintenance of order because it affects the locality and everybody who lives in the locality.

facts.text: Second ground involved preventing police from duties, affecting locality.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, in the second ground, he alongwith his associates prevented the police companystables from discharging their lawful duties and thus affected everybody living in the locality.

holdings.text: he alongwith his associates prevented the police constables from discharging their lawful duties and thus affected everybody living in the locality

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, in the second ground, he alongwith his associates prevented the police constables from discharging their lawful duties and thus affected everybody living in the locality.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Attack on police discharging duties terrorizes locality and prevents law enforcement affecting public at large

holdings.text: In ground No. 3, again the whole locality was in danger as the detenu and his associates were armed with deadly weapons and these were in fact used for indiscriminately endangering human lives in the locality

anchor.surface_text: In ground No. 3, again the whole locality was in danger as the detenu and his associates were armed with deadly weapons and these were in fact used for indiscriminately endangering human lives in the locality. The object of the detenu seems to have been to terrorise the locality and bring the whole machinery of law and order to a halt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Riot with bombs, brickbats, bottles hurled indiscriminately by armed group endangers entire area

anchor.surface_text: Pushkar Mukherjee Ors. v. The State of West Bengal 1 , in this companynection we must draw a line of demarcation between serious and aggravated forms of disorder which directly affect the companymunity or injure the public interest and the relatively minor breaches of peace of a purely local significance which primarily injure specific individuals and only in a secondary sense public interest.

h3 resolves whether ground relates to public order by finding it affects locality

anchor.surface_text: It is clearly said in ground No. 1 that he committed a riot and indiscriminately used acid bulbs, iron rods, lathis etc. endangering human lives. This ground cannot be said to have reference merely to maintenance of order because it affects the locality and everybody who lives in the locality.

Under these circumstances we are unable to say that there has been a breach of section 7. We trust that the State Government will number immediately deal with the representation or representations and pass a suitable order. It will be companyvenient to deal with the points 2 and 3 mentioned above together. It is true, as urged by the learned companynsel for the petitioner, that this Court has companysistently held that the grounds must have relevance to the maintenance of public order, and that they should number relate merely to the maintenance of order.
Similarly, in the second ground, he alongwith his associates prevented the police constables from discharging their lawful duties and thus affected everybody living in the locality.

Under these circumstances we are unable to say that there has been a breach of section 7. We trust that the State Government will number immediately deal with the representation or representations and pass a suitable order. It will be companyvenient to deal with the points 2 and 3 mentioned above together. It is true, as urged by the learned companynsel for the petitioner, that this Court has companysistently held that the grounds must have relevance to the maintenance of public order, and that they should number relate merely to the maintenance of order.

edges.explanation: h5 finds whole locality in danger from weapons, supporting c15

anchor.surface_text: In ground No. 3, again the whole locality was in danger as the detenu and his associates were armed with deadly weapons and these were in fact used for indiscriminately endangering human lives in the locality. The object of the detenu seems to have been to terrorise the locality and bring the whole machinery of law and order to a halt.

Under these circumstances we are unable to say that there has been a breach of section 7. We trust that the State Government will number immediately deal with the representation or representations and pass a suitable order. It will be companyvenient to deal with the points 2 and 3 mentioned above together. It is true, as urged by the learned companynsel for the petitioner, that this Court has companysistently held that the grounds must have relevance to the maintenance of public order, and that they should number relate merely to the maintenance of order.
